"Do you discourage the collegian's attempts
at writing verse?"
"No; it always ennobles a young man to attempt to write poetry, and it furthermore stimulates his interest in the study of poetry. Let
him write verses, if he will, for his own pleasure and for his friends ; but if he thinks he is a
born poet, and is to write poetry for publication, that—" said the Doctor, with a twinkle in
his keen blue eyes, "is another matter."
Professor Knight is the biographer of
Wordsworth, and editor of the latest and most
complete edition of the writings of that poet.
Among his other principal publications are,
"Poems from the Dawn of English Literature
to the Year 1699 (1863)." "Studies in Philosophy and Literature (1879)." "Essays in
Philosophy, Old and New (189o)." "The
Philosophy of the Beautiful," two volumes.
"The History, 1891, The Theory, 1893."

THE PRIZE DEBATE AND SPEAKING.

Convincing evidence of the value of the
forensic training which Mr. Guy Carleton Lee
has directed for the past five months was given
on Friday, March 25, to a large audience,
which attended the prize debate and prize
speaking in McCoy Hall.
The stage was attractively decorated with
palms and flags, and at a little past 8 o'clock
the representatives of the Senate and of the
House, attended by their advisory boards,
took their places at tables draped in the '98
and '99 class colors. President Gilman made
the introductory address and spoke of the revival of interest in public speaking and of its
importance to the college man.
Dean Griffin delivered the caution to the
freshman aspirants for honor in public speaking, who were divided into two sections. In
the first section D. M. Liddell spoke on "Our

National Defense, the Citizen Soldier," while
A. V. A. Schermerhorn delivered a "Speech
of Patrick Henry in 1775." The men and subjects in the second section were : Frederick
Foster, "Our Relations With England in
1824" ; W. P. Shriver, "Centennial Address," and Herbert Kaufman, "Universal
Emancipation." Professors Griffin, Greene
and Smith were judges of the speaking, and
awarded the prizes to Mr. Liddell and Mr.
Kaufman.
The main event of the evening was the debate between the classes of '98 and '99, over
which Mr. Lee presided. The question was :
"Shall Immigration to This Country be Further Restricted ?" Professor Adams warned
the " populace" not to disturb the speakers,
whom he especially urged to be "persuasive."
He cautioned the debaters to "begin slow,
speak low, rise higher ; take fire." The debate
was then opened by Mr. J. N. Ulman, who
eloquently presented arguments for the affirmative. He was followed by Mr. C. M. Guggenheimer, who spoke effectively for the negative. The convincing arguments which Mr.
C. M. Stearns coolly delivered were warmly
answered by Mr. P. S. Morgan. Mr. Z. M.
Ballard summed up the points made by the
seniors in a sarcastic address, which caused
considerable merriment. The debate was ably
closed by Mr. J. C. French, whose clear reasoning made it seem doubtful what the decision of the judges would be. After careful
consideration of the form and argument of the
debaters, Mr. William Marbury of the Baltimore Bar, on behalf of the judges, awarded
the prize to the seniors, who received a silver
trophy, which will shortly appear in the common room of the gymnasium.
Each of the winning speakers received a
gold medal, suitably engraved. The Banjo
Club, which played several selections, helped
materially to make the exercises a success.

All Hopkins men look pleased this week
over the happy termination of the relief bill.
Hurrah for the Maryland Legislature !

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. LANMAN'S LECTURES.

Dr. Charles Rockwell Lanman has just finished a most interesting course of lectures on
"The Poetry of India." All those who have a
poetical nature could not fail to be pleased and
delighted. The simple and beautiful hymns of
the Vedas, so poetically translated by the lecturer and other scholars of Sanskrit literature,
were a revelation to all. But they only served
to usher in that great Indian drama, "The
Sacontala ; or, The Fatal Ring." The marvelous beauty of this work opened up a new field
of vision to those who heard Dr. Lanman. In
it nature springs into life ; human sentiment
dwells in the flowers, the trees, the brook, the
wind, and all the mysteries of nature. Nature
and romanticism go hand in hand.
The philosophy of the Hindoos is none the
less unique than their poetry, and is exceedingly interesting.
Dr. Lanman took his A. B. at Yale in 1871,
and his Ph. D. in 1873. He was a favorite
pupil of Professor Whitney, the Orientalist.
After graduating at Yale, he studied in Berlin
and at other German universities. In 1876 he
came to Baltimore as a fellow of Sanskrit.
While here, Professor Bloomfield was his pupil
and took his doctor's degree under him. In
1877 he delivered a very successful course of
public lectures in Baltimore on Vedic literature. He was soon made associate professor
of Sanskrit. In 188o he went to Harvard as
professor of Sanskrit, and still resides there.
He was for many years the secretary of the
American Oriental Society, and has read
many valuable papers before that body.
Dr. Lanman and Dr. Bloomfield are considered to be the most eminent Sanskrit scholars
in this country.
Dr. Lanman has written two well-known
books : "Noun Inflection in the Vedas" and
"A Sanskrit Reader."
He has a very pleasing address, which
makes his lectures even more delightful.
No_one could attend them without becoming interested in that richness of local coloring
and imagery which is far more abundant in
Indian poetry than in our own.

OVERHEARD AT SANS SOUCI.

Said Frederick, the Great, one day,
While sitting with his friend Voltaire
Upon the terraced, broad parterre—
'Twas a rose-scented noon of May:
"I emphasize—each man, I say,
Should go to Heaven by his own way."
Behind them rose the old chateau.
Between the murmurs of the mill,
Far down the flower - wreathed, rosecrowned hill,
They heard the fountains' music flow.
Beyond, through the long avenue
The oaks enframed the distant view.
"I think you're wrong." The canny Gaul
Soon ventured, with a twinkling eye.
"I should prefer, before I die,
To try your way—the best of all.
So, just betwixt yourself and me,
I'll go to Heaven through Sans Souci."
"For here old Adam's lost estate
We for the nonce surely regain :
'Tis Eden, Paradise—here vain
The sword-armed angel at the gate.
Not travelers we. Far more 'tis worth
To have our Heaven upon Earth."
"We build," the King, slow-nodding, said,
"Our cloud-land Heaven from our dreams
Of by-gone Beauty, present gleams
Of Truth by errant Fancy led.
We wake somewhere, when run our race,
To find them deified in Space."
"Babes are but shadows of the man.
Man is a shadow of the soul.
This park through which our fancies stroll
Is but a token that we can
Seize for the moment,think or feel
A Heaven that faintly points the real."
The summer sun across the park
Still throws today its smile benign ;
The roses blush ; from yon old vine
His flute notes glorify the lark—
And just betwixt yourself and me
You'll find much heaven in Sans Souci.
J. McC. T., '96.

A public-speaking contest is not, as a rule,
to be classed under the head of pleasure-givA young man's maiden
ing institutions.
speech is apt to be of little interest to the general public and more or less excruciating to
his over-anxious friends. The recent interclass debate and public-speaking contest
seems, however, to have been in every way a
thoroughly interesting and creditable affair.
The audience was large and appreciative, and
the men made a remarkable showing, considering the very limited training they have received. While there seems to be a difference
of opinion as to the appropriateness of speaking "pieces" as a college performance, it is
certainly true that the said "pieces" were
well selected and carefully rendered. But
when the selection is just a bit too classical,
the well-known words will crowd the mind of
the listener long before the speaker can utter
them. It is to be hoped that next year the
speeches will be original.
The debate was lively and interesting
throughout. Though no important contributions seem to have been made to the information generally current upon the immigration

question, the speeches were well composed
and forcibly delivered. The men who closed
the debate deserve special comment for the
F
unusual ability to" think on their feet which
they displayed.
The effort to revive an interest in public
speaking has met with flattering results, and it
is not too much to hope that the University
will soon have many eloquent sons to guard
her interests. And it must not be forgotten
that whatever success we have achieved has
been solely due to the sound judgment and
enthusiastic perseverance of Mr. Guy Carleton
Lee, who has given so much of his time and
best efforts to this work. It remains for the
students to keep up the interest in the new
"Congress" which has been established, until
it shall become a time-honored feature of
Hopkins undergraduate life.

The three lectures of the Rev. Dr. Henry
Van Dyke, which were given recently in
McCoy Hall, were among the most delightful
of the year. The combined popularity of the
speaker and his subjects filled the hall to its
utmost capacity, making plain the fact that the
love of poetry is not yet dead among us. His
first lecture was on Wordsworth, whose theme
he said was Joy ; the second on Browning, whose theme was Courage and whose
work was marked by a restless, intellectual
curiosity, which the speaker made quite distinct from inquisitiveness; the third was on
Tennyson, whose theme was Symmetry,
Beauty, Harmony.
To Tennyson, Dr. Van Dyke gives the first
place among Nineteenth Century poets. He
has already published a volume on Tennyson,
and he is regarded as high authority in all
critical work pertaining to him, so that this
lecture was listened to with deep attention.
The Browning lecture was fine. There was
something akin to inspiration in the speaker,
and a great deal in the way of inspiration for
the hearer, with some very discriminating
words about Mr. Browning's poems.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
The House Committee of the New Gymnasium has, we are glad to see, taken active
steps to prevent students wearing heeled shoes
from entering the "cage." A rope has been
placed at the entrance to remind those who
are prone to forget the rules which have
We must
been framed for this purpose.
support our committee loyally, or more
stringent measures will have to be employed.
Besides, we surely ought to appreciate the
trouble and expense that has been experienced
to put our "cage" in the fine condition that
it is now in. What better way is there to
prove our appreciation than by strictly adhering to all rules adopted by our House Committee?

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Dr. John M. T. Finney, associate professor
of surgery, has been recently appointed by
Governor Lowndes chief surgeon of the First
Brigade, Maryland National Guard, with the
rank of Colonel, to succeed Dr. Johnson of the
Baltimore Medical School, resigned.
The long-expected book by Dr. Howard A.
Kelly made its appearance on Wednesday, and
may be seen in the postoffice. Only one volume has as yet been issued. Its title is"Operative Gynaecology," and it is published by
Appleton & Co. Dr. Kelly has put much valuable time on this work for several years past,
and its appearance has been eagerly looked
forward to by his pupils and colleagues.
The final examinations of the graduating
class are almost at hand. The practical examinations in Dr. Dobbins' department begin
in about a week.

nothing for the self-denial and hard work of
the men on the team ; that he is unwilling to
make any effort to repay the good which he
has received from Hopkins and from contact
with Hopkins men ; and, in a word, that he
does not possess the true spirit of devotion to
his Alma Mater which should characterize
every college student, and, above all, every
Johns Hopkins student. Let us hope that
there are few of this type.
It has been said that a new era is dawning
for Hopkins athletics. This may be so, or it
may not. The answer depends on us, the
undergraduates. Of the remainder of the University we cannot expect so much. Their
work is more pressing and more confining,
and it is natural that they should be able to
give little time to athletics. But with us the
case is different. The trustees of the University have done their part ; the coaches are
doing theirs ; the candidates for the teams
are working conscientiously ; and let us do
the same. Let us be willing to make some
sacrifice, to give up some other pleasure, for
the sake of supporting our athletics, and let us
realize that the man who does so will be working for Johns Hopkins as truly as her most
ardent supporter, and that, though his sacrifice may be unknown and unrecognized by the
college world, it will, nevertheless, be one of
which he may well be proud.
These suggestions are made to Johns Hopkins students. The matter is not one for the
special consideration of the governing board
of the association. It is a matter to be considered, as well, by every man whose vote
helped to create the governing board. It is a
matter about which every undergraduate and
graduate is entitled to an opinion. And it is

7

one about which every man ought to express
an opinion. A united body of undergraduates working harmoniously under a centralized assoication, in the best of quarters, if directed by knowledge and skill, would almost
excite us to brave the fate of him
without
honor in his own land." We would prophesy
that the time will come, and soon come, when
Hopkins men may take their friends to a Hopkins trophy-room, and proudly point to cups
and banners taken on field and track by Hopkins teams.
LACROSSE.

The scrub lacrosse team has been organized and will probably line up as follows :
Goal, Marshall ; P., Young; C. P., White;
1st D., Haskell ; 2d D., King; 3d D., Frank ;
centre, Raymann ; 3d A., Keidel ; 2d A., C.
Hodges (captain) ist A., Jungbluth ; 0.
H., Eager; I. H., E. Robinson.
Mr. Henry Bogue is manager.

BASEBALL.

The baseball games arranged with the Catholic University of Washington and the Maryland Agricultural College had to be canceled
on account of wet grounds.
Captain Clarke of the baseball team, who
has been ill for a short while, is better and able
to practice with the team.
Quite a number of lacrosse and baseballs
have lodged in the rafters of the cage. If this
state of affairs continues, the rafters may possess more of these balls by the end of the season than the Athletic Association.
Next Thursday the University baseball team
will start on a trip through Virginia and North
Carolina. Negotiations are also in progress
for a game with the University of the South
at Sewanee, Tenn.
The coming of spring at the Hopkins is announced by a chorus of croaking frogs in the
Biological Building.

THE PRIZE DEBATE AND SPEAKING.

Convincing evidence of the value of the
forensic training which Mr. Guy Carleton Lee
has directed for the past five months was given
on Friday, March 25, to a large audience,
which attended the prize debate and prize
speaking in McCoy Hall.
The stage was attractively decorated with
palms and flags, and at a little past 8 o'clock
the representatives of the Senate and of the
House, attended by their advisory boards,
took their places at tables draped in the '98
and '99 class colors. President Gilman made
the introductory address and spoke of the revival of interest in public speaking and of its
importance to the college man.
Dean Griffin delivered the caution to the
freshman aspirants for honor in public speaking, who were divided into two sections. In
the first section D. M. Liddell spoke on "Our

National Defense, the Citizen Soldier," while
A. V. A. Schermerhorn delivered a "Speech
of Patrick Henry in 1775." The men and subjects in the second section were : Frederick
Foster, "Our Relations With England in
1824" ; W. P. Shriver, "Centennial Address," and Herbert Kaufman, "Universal
Emancipation." Professors Griffin, Greene
and Smith were judges of the speaking, and
awarded the prizes to Mr. Liddell and Mr.
Kaufman.
The main event of the evening was the debate between the classes of '98 and '99, over
which Mr. Lee presided. The question was :
"Shall Immigration to This Country be Further Restricted ?" Professor Adams warned
the " populace" not to disturb the speakers,
whom he especially urged to be "persuasive."
He cautioned the debaters to "begin slow,
speak low, rise higher ; take fire." The debate
was then opened by Mr. J. N. Ulman, who
eloquently presented arguments for the affirmative. He was followed by Mr. C. M. Guggenheimer, who spoke effectively for the negative. The convincing arguments which Mr.
C. M. Stearns coolly delivered were warmly
answered by Mr. P. S. Morgan. Mr. Z. M.
Ballard summed up the points made by the
seniors in a sarcastic address, which caused
considerable merriment. The debate was ably
closed by Mr. J. C. French, whose clear reasoning made it seem doubtful what the decision of the judges would be. After careful
consideration of the form and argument of the
debaters, Mr. William Marbury of the Baltimore Bar, on behalf of the judges, awarded
the prize to the seniors, who received a silver
trophy, which will shortly appear in the common room of the gymnasium.
Each of the winning speakers received a
gold medal, suitably engraved. The Banjo
Club, which played several selections, helped
materially to make the exercises a success.

All Hopkins men look pleased this week
over the happy termination of the relief bill.
Hurrah for the Maryland Legislature !

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. LANMAN'S LECTURES.

Dr. Charles Rockwell Lanman has just finished a most interesting course of lectures on
"The Poetry of India." All those who have a
poetical nature could not fail to be pleased and
delighted. The simple and beautiful hymns of
the Vedas, so poetically translated by the lecturer and other scholars of Sanskrit literature,
were a revelation to all. But they only served
to usher in that great Indian drama, "The
Sacontala ; or, The Fatal Ring." The marvelous beauty of this work opened up a new field
of vision to those who heard Dr. Lanman. In
it nature springs into life ; human sentiment
dwells in the flowers, the trees, the brook, the
wind, and all the mysteries of nature. Nature
and romanticism go hand in hand.
The philosophy of the Hindoos is none the
less unique than their poetry, and is exceedingly interesting.
Dr. Lanman took his A. B. at Yale in 1871,
and his Ph. D. in 1873. He was a favorite
pupil of Professor Whitney, the Orientalist.
After graduating at Yale, he studied in Berlin
and at other German universities. In 1876 he
came to Baltimore as a fellow of Sanskrit.
While here, Professor Bloomfield was his pupil
and took his doctor's degree under him. In
1877 he delivered a very successful course of
public lectures in Baltimore on Vedic literature. He was soon made associate professor
of Sanskrit. In 188o he went to Harvard as
professor of Sanskrit, and still resides there.
He was for many years the secretary of the
American Oriental Society, and has read
many valuable papers before that body.
Dr. Lanman and Dr. Bloomfield are considered to be the most eminent Sanskrit scholars
in this country.
Dr. Lanman has written two well-known
books : "Noun Inflection in the Vedas" and
"A Sanskrit Reader."
He has a very pleasing address, which
makes his lectures even more delightful.
No_one could attend them without becoming interested in that richness of local coloring
and imagery which is far more abundant in
Indian poetry than in our own.

3

OVERHEARD AT SANS SOUCI.

Said Frederick, the Great, one day,
While sitting with his friend Voltaire
Upon the terraced, broad parterre—
'Twas a rose-scented noon of May:
"I emphasize—each man, I say,
Should go to Heaven by his own way."
Behind them rose the old chateau.
Between the murmurs of the mill,
Far down the flower - wreathed, rosecrowned hill,
They heard the fountains' music flow.
Beyond, through the long avenue
The oaks enframed the distant view.
"I think you're wrong." The canny Gaul
Soon ventured, with a twinkling eye.
"I should prefer, before I die,
To try your way—the best of all.
So, just betwixt yourself and me,
I'll go to Heaven through Sans Souci."
"For here old Adam's lost estate
We for the nonce surely regain :
'Tis Eden, Paradise—here vain
The sword-armed angel at the gate.
Not travelers we. Far more 'tis worth
To have our Heaven upon Earth."
"We build," the King, slow-nodding, said,
"Our cloud-land Heaven from our dreams
Of by-gone Beauty, present gleams
Of Truth by errant Fancy led.
We wake somewhere, when run our race,
To find them deified in Space."
"Babes are but shadows of the man.
Man is a shadow of the soul.
This park through which our fancies stroll
Is but a token that we can
Seize for the moment,think or feel
A Heaven that faintly points the real."
The summer sun across the park
Still throws today its smile benign ;
The roses blush ; from yon old vine
His flute notes glorify the lark—
And just betwixt yourself and me
You'll find much heaven in Sans Souci.
J. McC. T., '96.

A public-speaking contest is not, as a rule,
to be classed under the head of pleasure-givA young man's maiden
ing institutions.
speech is apt to be of little interest to the general public and more or less excruciating to
his over-anxious friends. The recent interclass debate and public-speaking contest
seems, however, to have been in every way a
thoroughly interesting and creditable affair.
The audience was large and appreciative, and
the men made a remarkable showing, considering the very limited training they have received. While there seems to be a difference
of opinion as to the appropriateness of speaking "pieces" as a college performance, it is
certainly true that the said "pieces" were
well selected and carefully rendered. But
when the selection is just a bit too classical,
the well-known words will crowd the mind of
the listener long before the speaker can utter
them. It is to be hoped that next year the
speeches will be original.
The debate was lively and interesting
throughout. Though no important contributions seem to have been made to the information generally current upon the immigration

question, the speeches were well composed
and forcibly delivered. The men who closed
the debate deserve special comment for the
F
unusual ability to" think on their feet which
they displayed.
The effort to revive an interest in public
speaking has met with flattering results, and it
is not too much to hope that the University
will soon have many eloquent sons to guard
her interests. And it must not be forgotten
that whatever success we have achieved has
been solely due to the sound judgment and
enthusiastic perseverance of Mr. Guy Carleton
Lee, who has given so much of his time and
best efforts to this work. It remains for the
students to keep up the interest in the new
"Congress" which has been established, until
it shall become a time-honored feature of
Hopkins undergraduate life.

The three lectures of the Rev. Dr. Henry
Van Dyke, which were given recently in
McCoy Hall, were among the most delightful
of the year. The combined popularity of the
speaker and his subjects filled the hall to its
utmost capacity, making plain the fact that the
love of poetry is not yet dead among us. His
first lecture was on Wordsworth, whose theme
he said was Joy ; the second on Browning, whose theme was Courage and whose
work was marked by a restless, intellectual
curiosity, which the speaker made quite distinct from inquisitiveness; the third was on
Tennyson, whose theme was Symmetry,
Beauty, Harmony.
To Tennyson, Dr. Van Dyke gives the first
place among Nineteenth Century poets. He
has already published a volume on Tennyson,
and he is regarded as high authority in all
critical work pertaining to him, so that this
lecture was listened to with deep attention.
The Browning lecture was fine. There was
something akin to inspiration in the speaker,
and a great deal in the way of inspiration for
the hearer, with some very discriminating
words about Mr. Browning's poems.

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Dr. John M. T. Finney, associate professor
of surgery, has been recently appointed by
Governor Lowndes chief surgeon of the First
Brigade, Maryland National Guard, with the
rank of Colonel, to succeed Dr. Johnson of the
Baltimore Medical School, resigned.
The long-expected book by Dr. Howard A.
Kelly made its appearance on Wednesday, and
may be seen in the postoffice. Only one volume has as yet been issued. Its title is"Operative Gynaecology," and it is published by
Appleton & Co. Dr. Kelly has put much valuable time on this work for several years past,
and its appearance has been eagerly looked
forward to by his pupils and colleagues.
The final examinations of the graduating
class are almost at hand. The practical examinations in Dr. Dobbins' department begin
in about a week.

an engagement," or, "I have a quiz tomorrow," or, the worst possible excuse,"I don't
want to go." If a man really has an important
engagement, or if he absolutely must work,
very well. It is not lack of loyalty that keeps
him from the field. But the case of the man
who "doesn't want to go"is far more serious.
Such an excuse shows that he is indifferent to
the best interests of his college ; that he cares
nothing for the self-denial and hard work of
the men on the team ; that he is unwilling to
make any effort to repay the good which he
has received from Hopkins and from contact
with Hopkins men ; and, in a word, that he
does not possess the true spirit of devotion to
his Alma Mater which should characterize
every college student, and, above all, every
Johns Hopkins student. Let us hope that
there are few of this type.
It has been said that a new era is dawning
for Hopkins athletics. This may be so, or it
may not. The answer depends on us, the
undergraduates. Of the remainder of the University we cannot expect so much. Their
work is more pressing and more confining,
and it is natural that they should be able to
give little time to athletics. But with us the
case is different. The trustees of the University have done their part ; the coaches are
doing theirs ; the candidates for the teams
are working conscientiously ; and let us do
the same. Let us be willing to make some
sacrifice, to give up some other pleasure, for
the sake of supporting our athletics, and let us
realize that the man who does so will be working for Johns Hopkins as truly as her most
ardent supporter, and that, though his sacrifice may be unknown and unrecognized by the
college world, it will, nevertheless, be one of
which he may well be proud.
These suggestions are made to Johns Hopkins students. The matter is not one for the
special consideration of the governing board
of the association. It is a matter to be considered, as well, by every man whose vote
helped to create the governing board. It is a
matter about which every undergraduate and
graduate is entitled to an opinion. And it is

The baseball games arranged with the Catholic University of Washington and the Maryland Agricultural College had to be canceled
